*The '''sokha''' is a light wooden [[plough]] which could be pulled by one horse. Its origin was in the north [[Russia]], most likely in the [[Novgorod Republic]], where it was used at least since the 13th century. A characteristic feature of sokha construction is the bifurcated plowing tip (ÑÐ°ÑÑÐ¾ÑÐ°), so that a sokha has two plowshares, later made of metal, which cut the soil. Sokha is an evolution of a [[scratch-plough]] by an addition of a [[spade]]-like detail which turns the cut soil over (in regular ploughs the curved [[mouldboard]] both cuts and turns the soil).<ref>[http://bibliotekar.ru/rusNovgorod/86.htm The study of the history of ancient ploughs of the Novgorod land] by V.
